comment._content:
General Wainwright had been a Prisoner Of War held by the Japanese - which accounts for his emaciation visible in this photograph.

Due to the privations he had suffered while a POW, he was accorded the honor (I think  by General MacArthur) of being present at the surrender ceremony aboard USS Missouri on September 2, 1945 where he saw all the signatures affixed to the document he is unveiling here.

Unveiling this document is a further honor which was accorded to he and his wife.

comment._content: There's more. And this is really good. The U.S. National Archives later put out a pamphlet with another photograph of this scene with Gen. Wainwright giving his speech before the unveiling. It includes tells the journey of the documents and gives the complete text of Wainwright's speech as well as the speech of Solon J. Buck, Archivist of the United States. National Archives Publication 46 - 6. See it here: reta.nmsu.edu/bataan/curriculum/resources/historical resources/surrender_docs.pdf Gen. Wainwright refers in his speech to Gen MacArthur presenting him with the first pen he used to sign the document. There is newsreel footage of that occasion available on YouTube (and in your Archives no doubt) see the even at 5:30 here, www.youtube.com/watch?v=vcnH_kF1zXc
